Unix-intro.question: what is Unix?
Unix-intro.ans: It is an operating system which is a special software that controls the hardware of a computer system

Unix-intro.question: Is Unix and Linux same?
Unix-intro.ans: No, they are not. Linux is derived from Unix. Linux is used with GNU (an OS) which stands for GNU is Not Unix

Unix-intro.question: Why use UNIX?
Unix-intro.ans: it provides modularity, portability, simplicity, adapility, highly secured, and Linux os is everywhere!

File-management.question: ls
File-management.ans: lists all “visible” files in current directory

File-management.question: ls -la
File-management.ans: Lists all files in current directory and presents them in a long list format.

File-management.question: cp <filename1> <filename2>
File-management.ans: copy existing filename1 into new filename2.

File-management.question: cp -r <dir1> <dir2>
File-management.ans: “copy”, recursively. copy existing contents of directory1 into directory2.

File-management.question: rm <filename1> <filename2>
File-management.ans: remove filename1 and filename2. * Not reversible!

File-management.question: rm -r <directory1>'
File-management.ans: remove recursively directory1 and all its contents. * Not reversible!

File-management.question: mv <file1> <directory1>
File-management.ans: move file1 into directory1. * Not reversible!

File-management.question: cat <file1> > <file2>
File-management.ans: Overwite the contents of file2 with the contents of file1.

File-management.question: cat <file1> >> <file2>
File-management.ans: Write the contents of file1 to the end of file2.

File-management.question: cat <file1> >> <file2>
File-management.ans: Write the contents of file1 to the end of file2.

File-management.question: cat *.txt
File-management.ans: Show the content of all text files present in the folder.

File-management.question: What is tar commands?
File-management.ans: stands for tape archive, to create archive or extract archive files

File-management.question: tar -cvf dir_1.tar dir_1
File-management.ans: To bundle all the content of dir_1 into a single file called dir_1.tar

File-management.question: tar xvf file.tar
File-management.ans: To extract files for archive file

File-management.question: touch
File-management.ans: display content, one screen at the time

File-management.question: more
File-management.ans: display content, one screen at the time

Environment.question: man
Environment.ans: stand for manual, give you more information about the command

Environment.question: uname
Environment.ans: display information about the system

Environment.question: whoami
Environment.ans: show current active user

Environment.question: who
Environment.ans: gives information on current logged in users. It tells of the login name and time.

Environment.question: su
Environment.ans: stand for subtitute user ( often mistaken as super use)

Environment.question: passwd
Environment.ans: this command changes your password

Environment.question: whereis
Environment.ans: this command is used to find where a command exists

Environment.question: whatis
Environment.ans: quickly see an single line description on what a command does

Environment.question: ps
Environment.ans: display all the current processes owned by the current user

Environment.question: ctrl-c
Environment.ans: terminate a process

Environment.question: ctrl-d
Environment.ans: terminate an external preocess

Environment.question: ctrl-z
Environment.ans: suspends a job

Environment.question: bg
Environment.ans: resume the suspended jobs in the background

Environment.question: fg
Environment.ans: resume the suspended jobs in the foreground

Environment.question: top
Environment.ans: gives you real time resource usage by job for the machine. Terminates with ctrl-c

Environment.question: ssh
Environment.ans: a protocol that a secure connection between two hosts (remote) over an insecure network

Environment.question: scp
Environment.ans: a protocol that copies a file from a local computer onto a remote host

Environment.question: ifconfig
Environment.ans: view or configure a network.

Environment.question: ping
Environment.ans: see if a server is available and there is a connection between two nodes

Environment.question: g++
Environment.ans: used in c++ development for preprocessing, compiling, assembling, and linking source code to create an executable

Environment.question: kill
Environment.ans: terminate specific processes
see if a server is available and there is a connection between two nodes

Environment.question: du -sh ~
Environment.ans: tells the disk usage for your home directory.
